results.title: Chains of circumstance
results.brief_description: Three case histories of poverty show the work of the Freemasons’ Benevolent Institution in New South Wales. The Institution was founded in 1880 as a means of helping the aged, invalid and distressed. From a system of voluntary subscriptions, annuities are granted to those who need help.

results.title: Chain reaction
results.brief_description: A silent film without subtext about one’s bad humour on others. An office manager whose wife spills the tea on his morning paper upsets his wife, their children and his subordinates at work. No other credits available.

results.title: Ceylon: the new dominion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
A survey of the history and position (as at 1948) of Ceylon (Sri Lanka), the newest Dominion of the British Commonwealth. Shows the civilization of the Lion People who invaded Ceylon from Northern India; the influence of Portugese and Dutch colonization which preceded British rule. The achievements of a 150 years of British rule are evaluated. The practical results of British government in terms of increased production of tea, rubber and coconuts are illustrated. Shows the modern educational system; defeat of malaria; extension of irrigation and recolonization of the north; difficulties facing the new Dominion. The population of six and a half million people is made up of five races with four religions and three languages. Poverty, lack of finance, high cost of imported food are barriers to progress, but progressive social schemes have been started.

results.title: Cervical cancer
results.creator_credit: A Ralph Rosenthal, Health Education Video Unit, Leicestershire Health Authority and Russell Kightley
results.brief_description: Details the structure of the cervix and explains why it is particularly vulnerable to external agents. Addresses the high incidence of cervical cancer and recommends preventative strategies.

results.title: Cerebral palsy: basic abilities
results.creator_credit: Spastic Centre of New South Wales
results.brief_description: Based on the Book “Cerebral Palsy - Basic Abilities - A plan for Training the Pre-School Child” the film carefully outlines the program used in New South Wales since 1963, in an attempt to develop visuomotor and perceptual learning skills.

results.title: Ceramic glazes
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the mixing of an opaque matt and stone glaze, both showing wide firing latitude and high colour receptivity. Glaze application by several methods is shown. Kiln interiors at intervals during firing show the progressive stages of the glaze.

results.title: Ceramic art of Japan
results.creator_credit: Nihon Eiga Shin-sha and Tokyo National Museum
results.brief_description: Ceramics, the traditional art of hands, clay and fire, began with the making of earthenware. Korean and Chinese influences can be traced in the history of Japanese ceramics but were modified by the existing traditions of the Japanese craftsmen. Exquisite work includes some dating from the ninth century, a tenth century jar with a beautiful ash-blown glaze; tea ceremony bowls of porcelain with plum blossom being used as a popular motif.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nihon Eiga Shin-sha and Tokyo National Museum

results.title: Century of progress
results.creator_credit: M. Bhavnani, Documentary Films of India and V.R. Sarma
results.brief_description: A survey of the Indian Railways, the story of the fulfilment of a 100-year-old dream. April 16, 1953, marked the first centenary of the Indian Railways. In 1853 the first rails were laid between Bombay and Thana. Where once only the hoof-beat of the bullock or pony could be heard, the iron horse now thunders. India now possesses the largest railway system in Asia and the third largest in the world. Commentary by Berkeley Hill.
